Guide to the Greene Avenue Baptist Church records
                    <num>1985.071</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Patricia Glowinski

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2011-11-18T16:58-0500</date>

extent.value: in one and a half manuscript boxes and one volume.

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The Greene Avenue Baptist Church records span the years 1854 to 1950 and consist of seven volumes of church records including one register, three volumes of membership lists, and three volumes of church minutes. Formerly the First Baptist Church of Bushwick, the Greene Avenue Baptist Church was established on April 15, 1854. The church moved three times in its 96 years of existence. The first place of worship was on Bushwick Avenue in a private home. From 1884 to 1888, Warner's Hall was used for church functions and gatherings. The new church building, completed in April of 1888, was located on Greene Avenue, between Lewis and Stuyvesant Avenues, in what is today the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Greene Avenue Baptist Church records, 1985.071, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.
Gift of Harold J. Manson, date unknown. The collection was formally accessioned in 1985.

Formerly the First Baptist Church of Bushwick, the Greene Avenue Baptist Church was established on April 15, 1854. The church moved three times in its 96 years of existence. The first place of worship was on Bushwick Avenue in a private home. From 1884 to 1888, Warner's Hall was used for church functions and gatherings. The new church building, completed in April of 1888, was located on Greene Avenue, between Lewis and Stuyvesant Avenues, in what is today the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn. The church building was purchased by Antioch Baptist Church in 1950.
Volume 7; dated June 1945 to January 1950, is a minute book recording church meetings, baptisms, and resolutions.
